points.title: Yahoo's copyright license for photos, graphics, audio and video limited for purpose

topics.description: Copyright law gives you control over how your content (texts, photos, videos, etc.) can be used, by whom they can be distributed, modified, etc. Sometimes, online services need your permission to perform certain tasks with your content. That's why they ask you to grant them a copyright license. But sometimes, the copyright license is so broad, that your content can be exploited by others without asking you.

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. topics.name: Scope of the copyright license
topics.subtitle: Do you grant only the necessary rights?
topics.title: Scope of the copyright license

tosdr.case: limited for purpose of same service
tosdr.tldr: The copyright license granted to Yahoo for photos, graphics, audio and video is limited “solely for the purpose for which such Content was submitted or made available”.

topics.description: Cookies are files stored locally in your web browser containing identifiable information.

topics.name: Cookies
topics.subtitle: and related technologies
topics.title: Cookies

tosdr.tldr: Yahoo sets and uses cookies on your computer. This gives Yahoo both identifiable (when you are signed in) and anonymous (when you are signed out) forms of information about you, your preferences and behaviour. You can choose to reject all cookies in your browser but this may prevent you from using Yahoo services that require you to sign in. To track you on other Yahoo Services’ sites and across the web, Yahoo may also use web beacons that act in a similar way to cookies and gather and contain information about your web browsing behaviour

points.title: Your account can be suspended for several reasons

topics.description: Your account and your data are on their servers, so they control them. Which guarantee do you have that lawful content and lawful activity will not be censored or suspended?

To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Suspension and Censorship
topics.subtitle: Can they end your use of the service at any time?
topics.title: Suspension and Censorship

tosdr.case: they can suspend your account for several reasons
tosdr.tldr: “Section 15: Termination … You agree that Yahoo! may, without prior notice, immediately terminate, limit your access to or suspend your Yahoo! account, any associated email address, and access to the Yahoo! Services. Cause for such termination, limitation of access or suspension shall include, but not be limited to, (a) breaches or violations of the TOS or other incorporated agreements or guidelines, (b)requests by law enforcement or other government agencies, (c) discontinuance or material modification to the Yahoo! Services (or any part thereof), (d) unexpected technical or security issues or problems, (e) extended periods of inactivity, (f) engagement by you in fraudulent or illegal activities, and/or (g) nonpayment of any fees owed by you in connection with the Yahoo! Services. Further, you agree that all terminations, limitations of access and suspensions for cause shall be made in Yahoo!'s sole discretion and that Yahoo! shall not be liable to you or any third party for any termination of your account, any associated email address, or access to the Yahoo! Services.”

topics.description: Copyright law gives you control over how your content (texts, photos, videos, etc.) can be used, by whom they can be distributed, modified, etc. Sometimes, online services need your permission to perform certain tasks with your content. That's why they ask you to grant them a copyright license. But sometimes, the copyright license is so broad, that your content can be exploited by others without asking you.

topics.name: Scope of the copyright license
topics.subtitle: Do you grant only the necessary rights?
topics.title: Scope of the copyright license

tosdr.case: limited for purpose of same service
tosdr.tldr: The copyright license granted to Yahoo “With respect to Content you submit or make available for inclusion on publicly accessible areas of Yahoo! Groups, the license to use, distribute, reproduce, modify, adapt, publicly perform and publicly display such Content on the Yahoo! Services solely for the purposes of providing and promoting the specific Yahoo! Group to which such Content was submitted or made available. This license exists only for as long as you elect to continue to include such Content on the Yahoo! Services and will terminate at the time you remove or Yahoo! removes such Content from the Yahoo! Services.”

topics.name: Law enforcement and due process
topics.subtitle: What are the law enforcement standards followed by the service?
topics.title: Law enforcement and due process

tosdr.tldr: This service makes clear to their users what standards and rules law enforcement must follow when they seek access to sensitive user data.

points.title: Terms may be changed at any time without advance notice

topics.description: Services need to evolve. But it is important that updating the service does not break the consentment with the user. Updates and changes to terms of service and privacy policy need to be properly noticed to users and to sollicit their agreement again.

To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Notice of Changing Terms
topics.subtitle: Are users notified when terms change? Are they given enough time to find out what changed and discuss this with each other before deciding whether to continue to use the service under the new terms?
topics.title: Notice of Changing Terms

tosdr.tldr: The service can change the terms of service at any time, even without notification to the user. New or updated terms are posted on their site but your continued use of the service is taken as acceptance of the new or changed terms.

topics.title: Cookies

tosdr.tldr: Yahoo lets its advertisers set and access their cookies and web beacons on your computer. These cookies and web beacons and their use are subject to their own privacy policies, not Yahoo’s privacy policy.

topics.title: Law and government requests

tosdr.tldr: This service informs users when their data is sought by the government, unless prohibited by law. With this knowledge, you have an opportunity to involve yourself if you think the request is unreasonable.

points.title: You must provide your legal name upon registration

topics.description: The terms sometimes describe the level of logging and the level of data collection and which kinds of data the service is processing. Anonymity or the right to use a pseudonym can be very important for freedom of expression (e.g. for people exercising a certain profession, or people living in authoritarian regimes).

topics.name: Anonymity and Tracking
topics.subtitle: Are you being spied on?
topics.title: Anonymity and Tracking

tosdr.case: pseudonym not allowed (not because of user-to-user trust)
tosdr.tldr: You agree to provide your full legal name when you register to the service. It does not prevent you from using a pseudonym.

points.title: Yahoo deletes your account after 90 days yet copied information in back-up storage may be kept for an undefined period of time after your deletion request.

topics.description: Once you subscribe to the service, will you have the right to leave it and remove your data?

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Right to leave the service
topics.subtitle: To avoid lock-in and stay in control
topics.title: Right to leave the service

tosdr.tldr: If you ask Yahoo to delete your account, in most cases your account will be deactivated and then deleted from their user registration database in approximately 90 days. If they have copied information to back-up storage it could remain there for an undefined period of time.
